questions.text: External genitalia develops at
questions.solution:
External genitalia develops at 8-12 weeks post conception.

Principal Events of Embryonic and Fetal Development:

Days 14–21 post conception
  • Notochord develops.
  • Ectoderm thickens to form neural plate and neural folds.
 
Days 21–28 post conception
  • Neural folds fuse to form neural tube, four primitive cardiac chambers
  • First heart beats on D-21
 
Weeks 4–6 post conception (4–15 mm embryo)
  • Optic vesicles appear, complete neural tube closure (D-30)
  • Limb buds appear.
  • Formation of face
 
Weeks 6–8 post conception (15–30 mm embryo)
  • All major structures form, complete ventricular septum (D-46)
  • recognizably human
 
Weeks 8–12 post conception (30–60 mm embryo)
  • External genitalia develops
Weeks—20
  • Skin is covered with lanugo.
  • Vernix caseosa is present.
 
Weeks—28
  • Testes descend to the internal inguinal ring.
  • Baby is viable
 
Weeks—36
  • One testicle usually descends into the scrotum.
  •  Lanugo tends to disappear
 
Weeks—40
  • Both the testicles descend into the scrotum. Nails project beyond the finger tips.    
  • Posterior fontanel is closed

questions.text: Fetal blood flow through placenta per minute is
questions.solution:
• Fetal blood flow through placenta per minute is 400 ml.

Fetal Hemodynamics

Fetal blood flow through the placenta 400 mL/min
Pressure in the umbilical artery 60 mm Hg
Pressure in the umbilical vein 10 mm Hg
Fetal capillary pressure in villi 20–40 mm Hg

 

  Umbilicalartery Umbilicalvein
O2 saturation 50–60% 70–80%
PO2 20–25 mm Hg 30–40 mm Hg

 

Intervillous Hemodynamics

Volume of blood in mature placenta  500 mL
Volume of blood in inter villousSpace  150 mL
Blood flow in inter villous space  500–600 mL/min
Pressure in inter villous space-During uterine contraction  30–50 mm Hg
Pressure in inter villous space-During uterine relaxation  10–15 mm Hg

questions.text: Arias-Stella reaction is seen in
questions.solution:
Arias-Stella reaction is seen in

  • Uterine and ectopic pregnancy
  • Endometriosis
  • Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD)

Arias-Stella reaction:

  • In some cases of uterine and ectopic pregnancies, the endo­metrium shows intense adenomatous and hyper secretive activity within the glandular epithelium.
  • The cells are enlarged; epithelial nuclei show mitosis, hyperchromasia, polyploidy and atypical cell types.
  • The cells are hyper secretive without glycogen content.
  • These changes are focal and often as­sociated with decidual reaction in the stroma.
  • This endometrial reaction is seen in endometriosis, reaction to oestrogen and to gonadotropins, as well as in gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD).

questions.text: True statement regarding Braxton-Hicks contraction is

choices.text: The contraction is frequent and painful
Intra uterine pressure remains above 8 mm Hg
It is not felt in abdominal pregnancy
Contractions cannot be felt during bimanual palpation

questions.solution:
In abdominal pregnancy, Braxton-Hicks contraction is not felt. Only felt in intrauterine pregnancy.

  • From the very early weeks of pregnancy, the uterus undergoes spontaneous contraction.
  • Can be felt during bimanual palpation in early weeks or during abdominal palpation when the uterus feels firmer at one moment and softer at another.
  • The contractions may be excited by rubbing the uterus.
  • The contractions are irregular, infrequent, spasmodic and painless without any effect on dilatation of the cervix.
  • The patient is not conscious about the contractions. 
  • Intrauterine pressure remains below 8 mm Hg.
  • Near term, the contractions become frequent with increase in intensity so as to produce some discomfort to the patient.
  • It merges with the painful uterine contractions of labor.

questions.text: Placental sign denotes

choices.text: Cyclical bleeding occurs up to 12 weeks of pregnancy
Irregular bleeding occurs up to 12 weeks of pregnancy
Cyclical bleeding occurs up to 18 weeks of pregnancy
Irregular bleeding occurs up to 18 weeks of pregnancy

questions.solution:
• Cyclic bleeding may occur up to 12 weeks of pregnancy, until the decidual space is obliterated by the fusion of decidua vera with decidua capsularis.
  • Bleeding is usually scanty, lasting for a shorter duration than her usual and roughly corresponds with the date of the expected period.

questions.text: Depressed fontanels are seen with
questions.solution:
Depressed fontanel seen with dehydration.

Large fontanels

  • Hypothyroidism
  • Osteogenesis imperfect
  • Chromosomal anomalies (Down syndrome)

Bulging fontanel

  • Increased intracranial pressure
  • Meningitis or hydrocephalus

Small fontanel

  • Hyperthyroidism

Microcephaly or craniosynostosis.

questions.text: Funic souffle is due to increased blood flow in
questions.solution:
Funic or fetal souffle

  • Due to the rush of blood through the umbilical arteries.
  • It is a soft, blowing murmur synchronous with the fetal heart sounds.

Uterine souffle

  • Is a soft blowing and systolic murmur heard low down at the sides of the uterus, best on the left side.
  • The sound is synchronous with the maternal pulse and is due to increase in blood flow through the dilated uterine vessels.
  • It can be heard in big uterine fibroid.

questions.text: The given image represents fetus in which presentation
questions.solution:
The give image represents fetus in vertex presentation with deflexed head.

Other presentations are:

questions.text: Which of the following is used as a source of stem cells in stem cell therapy
questions.solution:
The sources of stem cells were until recently seen in bone marrow, embryo, amniotic fluid and umbilical cord blood but now in menstrual fluid as well.

Menstrual fluid:

  • The menstrual fluid contains mesenchymal cells such as mononuclear cells and fibroblasts.
  • These cells deteriorate with advanc­ing age.
  • Therefore, cells from young women are suitable for donation, and self-use at a later age if needed.
  • The kit con­tains antibiotics to prevent infection, and the menstrual fluid is cryopreserved and harvested.

The procedure is sim­ple, non invasive and painless as well as possible.

questions.text: Which of the following is the largest diameter of the fetal skull
questions.solution:
• Mento vertical is the largest diameter of the fetal skull-14 cm.

                                   Diameters of fetal skull

Diameters Measurement in cm (inches) Attitude of the head Presentation
Suboccipitobregmatic 9.5 cm Complete flexion  Vertex 
Suboccipito-frontal 10 cm Incomplete flexion  Vertex 
Occupitofrontal 11.5 cm Marked deflexion  Vertex 
Mento-vertical 14 cm Partial extension  Brow 
Submentovertical 11.5 cm Incomplete extension  Face 
Submentobregmatic 9.5 cm Complete extension  Face

questions.text: Maternal serum alpha protein raised in all of the following conditions except
questions.solution:
• Low level of maternal serum alpha protein seen in Gestational trophoblastic disease.

Conditions associated with increased and decreased maternal serum alpha feto protein level

             Increased in                     Decreased in
  • Wrong gestational age
  • Open neural tube defects (NTDs)
  • Multiple pregnancy
  • Rh isoimmunisation
  • IUFD
  • Anterior abdominal wall defects
  • Renal anomalies
  • Trisomies (Down’s syndrome)
  • Gestational trophoblastic disease.

questions.text: Formation of mature adult breast occurs in which stage of breast development
questions.solution:
Formation of mature adult breast occur in stage 5 of breast development.

Thelarche

  • The first sign of puberty is the development of the breasts.
  • Breast budding usually appears between the ages of 9–11 years; it is indicative of the competency of the hypothalamic– pituitary–ovarian axis.

Stages

  • B1—Denotes the prepubertal breast. At this infantile stage only the papilla is elevated.
  • B2—Denotes thelarche. The breast buds are palpable, areola enlarges and the breast is elevated like a small mound.
  • B3—There is further enlargement of the breast and its areola without separation of its contours.
  • B4—Preferential growth of the areola and nipple leads to for­mation of a secondary mound over the mound of the breast.
  • B5—Formation of the mature adult breast. There is recession of the areola into the general contour of the breast be­cause of greater growth of the breast tissue.

Pubic Hair Development

The stages of pubic hair growth are as follows: 

  • P1—prepubertal stage when there are no coarse pubic hair present, the vellus hair present over the pubic area are similar to the ones seen over the abdominal wall.
  • P2—pubarche denotes the appearance of long or slightly curved and pigmented hair sparsely over the labia.
  • P3—darker, coarser and curly hair are seen spread over the mons pubis.
  • P4—the pre adult stage when thick dark growths of curly hair are seen covering the area short of the inverted triangle
  • P5—adult inverted triangular distribution of thick, coarse, dark curly hair spreading out towards the medial aspects of the thighs.

Axillary Hair Development

The sequence of axillary hair development is as follows:

  • A1—prepubertal stage. No axillary hair present.
  • A2—appearance of sparse axillary hair.
  • A3—adult distribution of thick, coarse and dark pigmented hair.

questions.text: The risk of fetal loss is highest in which of the following procedure
questions.solution:
The risk of fetal loss is highest in cordocentesis.

                                               Prenatal diagnosis

  Chorionic villus sampling Amniocentesis Cordocentesis
Time Transcervical 10–13 weeks,Transabdominal 10 weeks to term  After 15 weeks (early12–14 weeks) 18–20 weeks
Materials for study Trophoblast cells Fetal  fibroblasts fluid for biochemical study  Fetal white blood cells (others—infection andbiochemical study)
Karyotype result Direct preparation: 24–48 hours.Culture: 10–14 days Culture:3–4 weeks   Culture:24–48 hours
Fetal loss 0.5–1% 0.5%  1–2%
Accuracy Accurate; may need amniocentesis for confirmation  Highly accurate Highly accurate

questions.text: Which of the following is not a classical triad of ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• The classic triad of symptoms of disturbed tubal pregnancy are:
    • Abdominal pain (100%)
    • Amenorrhea (75%)
    • Appearance of vaginal bleeding (70%)

Amenorrhea:

  • Short period of 6–8 weeks (usually); there may be delayed period or history of vaginal spotting.
  • Amenorrhea may be absent even.

Abdominal pain is the most constant feature.

  • It is acute, agonizing or colicky.
  • Pain is located at lower abdomen: unilateral, bilateral or may be generalized.
  • Shoulder tip pain (25%) (referred pain due to diaphragmatic irritation from hemoperitoneum) may be present.

 

  • Vaginal bleeding may be slight and continuous.
  • Vomiting, fainting attack. Syncopal attack (10%) is due to reflex vasomotor disturbances following peritoneal irritation from hemoperitoneum.

questions.text: Climacteric is related to:
questions.solution:
Climacteric is the phase of waning ovarian activity, and may begin 2–3 years before menopause and continue for 2–5 years after it.

The climacteric is thus a phase of adjust­ment between the active and inactive ovarian function and occupies several years of a woman’s life, and it involves physical, sexual and psychological adjustments.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image
questions.solution:
The condition given in the image is inevitable abortion.

Inevitable abortion:

  • It is the clinical type of abortion where the changes have progressed to a state from where continuation of pregnancy is impossible.
  • Internal examination reveals dilated internal os of the cervix through which the products of conception are felt.
  • When the entire products of conception are not expelled, instead a part of it is left inside the uterine cavity, it is called incomplete miscarriage.
  • Threatened miscarriage is a clinical entity where the process of miscarriage has started but has not progressed to a state from which recovery is impossible.

questions.text: Spiegelberg‘s criteria used in diagnosis of
questions.solution:
Spiegelberg‘s criteria - ovarian pregnancy

  • Tube on the affected side must be intact.
  • The gestation sac must be in the position of the ovary.
  • The gestation sac is connected to the uterus by the ovarian ligament.
  • The ovarian tissue must be found on its wall on histological examination.

Studdiford criteria - abdominal pregnancy

  • Both the tubes and ovaries are normal without evidence of recent injury
  • Absence of uteroperitoneal fistula
  • Presence of a pregnancy related exclusively to the peritoneal surface and young enough to eliminate the possibility of secondary implantation following primary nidation in the tube

Rubin’s criteria - cervical pregnancy

  • Soft, enlarged cervix equal to or larger than the fundus.
  • Uterine bleeding following amenorrhea, without cramping pain.
  • Products of conception entirely confined within and firmly attached to endocervix.
  • A closed internal cervical os and a partially opened external os.

questions.text: False statement regarding Hormone replacement therapy is

choices.text: All women require Hormone replacement therapy after menopause
Associated with increased risk of ovarian cancer

questions.solution:
• Not all women require HRT after menopause.
  • Besides, HRT does not suit all, and it may cause complication and be harmful.
  • However, it is logical to prescribe HRT and not withhold it when one needs it in the minimal effective dose for the shortest needed duration under supervision while on therapy.
  • Initially, every menopausal woman was advised to go on HRT as soon as menopause set in to be taken for several years.
  • Newer researches and their observations reveal that a few women need prophylactic and therapeutic HRT, but 70–85% of women remain healthy and need only good nutrition and healthy lifestyle.

Contraindications

  • Breast cancer, uterine cancer or family history of cancer
  • Previous history of thromboembolic episode
  • Liver and gall bladder diseases
  • Uterine fibroids—the fibroids may enlarge in size

Uses of HRT

  • Short term—hot flushes, vasomotor symptoms
  • Dyspareunia, libido
  • Urethral syndrome
  • Long term—osteoporosis
  • Cardiovascular disease
  • Alzheimer’s disease

Risks of HRT:

  • Endometrial cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Ovarian cancer
  • Thromboembolism
  • Lipid profile dysfunction
  • Gall stones, liver dysfunction

questions.text: Triploid karyotype seen in
questions.solution:
Triploid karyotype seen in partial mole.

Features Complete Mole Partial Mole
Embryo/Fetus Absent Present
Hydropic degeneration of villi Pronounced and diffused Variable and focal
Trophoblast hyperplasia Diffuse Focal
Uterine size More than the date (30–60%) Less than the date
Theca lutein cysts Common (25–50%) Uncommon
Karyotype 46, XX (85%), paternal in origin Triploid (90%), diploid (10%)
Risk of persistent GTN 20% <5%

questions.text: The condition shown in the given image is more commonly seen in
questions.solution:
• The condition shown in the image is Fetus papyraceous or compressus-more common in monozygotic twins.
  • It is a state which occurs if one of the fetuses dies early.
  • The dead fetus is flattened, mummified and compressed between the membranes of the living fetus and the uterine wall.

questions.text: Roll over test is done for
questions.solution:
Roll over test:

  • Screening test  for pre eclampsia is done between 28 and 32 weeks.
  • Blood pressure is measured with the patient on her side first and then the patient is asked to roll on her back to check the blood pressure once again.
  • An increase of 20 mm Hg in diastolic pressure from side to back position indicates a positive “roll over test”.
  • About 33% of women with positive “roll over test” developed hypertension later.

questions.text: How many grades are present in Papanicolaou classification
questions.solution:
There are 5 grades in papanocolaou classification.

Papanicolaou classification-5 grades

  • Grade I- Normal cells
  • Grade II -Slightly abnormal, suggestive of inflammatory change; repeat smear after treating the infection
  • Grade III- A more serious type of abnormality, usually in­dicative of the need for biopsy
  • Grade IV -Distinctly abnormal, possibly malignant and definitely requiring biopsy
  • Grade V- Malignant cells seen

questions.text: All of the following are biophysical predictor of pre term labour except
questions.solution:
Uterine contractions (UC) > 4/hr (not 2 hrs) is a biophysical predictor of preterm labor.

 

Predictors of preterm labor:

Clinical predictors:

  • History of prior preterm birth
  • Multiple pregnancy
  • Presence of genital tract infection
  • Symptoms of Pre term labor

Biophysical predictors:

  • Uterine contractions (UC) > 4/hr
  • Bishop score > 4
  • Cervical length (TVS) < 25 mm

Biochemical predictors:

  • Fetal fibronectin (fFN) in cervicovaginal discharge 
  • Others IL-6, IL-8, TNF-α

questions.text: In Intra uterine fetal death the blistering and the peeling of the skin occurs at
questions.solution: Blistering and peeling off of the skin occurs in maceration and it appears between 12 hours and 24 hours after death.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image
questions.solution:
The image shows the Buddha sign, seen in hydrops fetalis.

Buddha position of the fetus with a halo around the head due to an edematous scalp. This is the most serious form of Rh hemolytic disease (HDFN).

Excessive destruction of the fetal red cells leads to severe anemia, tissue anoxemia, and metabolic acidosis. Fetal death occurs sooner or later due to cardiac failure.

questions.text: All of the following are indications of colposcopy except
questions.solution:
Colposcopy indications

  • Abnormal Pap smear
  • Cervical lesion
  • Vaginal lesion
  • Vulval lesion
  • Follow-up of ablation therapy

Colposcopy of the vulva

  • Colposcopy of the vulva is not always informative because of keratinization and deep-seated vesselsand multiple lesions.
  • Toluidine blue shows heavy staining but does not give clue to the underlying pathology.
  • Biopsy is required.

Colposcopy of the vagina indications:

  • To evaluate vagina with abnormal Pap smear but normal colposcopic findings of the cervix.
  • Rule out extension of CIN.
  • Women with HPV viral infection.
  • Gross lesion present.
  • Follow-up of hysterectomy or conservative therapy performed for CIN disease.

questions.text: Which of the following combination of pelvis is not possible
questions.solution:
On the basis of the shape of the inlet, the female pelvis is divided into four parent types

  • Gynecoid (50%)
  • Anthropoid (25%)
  • Android (20%)
  • Platypelloid (5%)

- But more commonly, intermediate forms with combination of features are found,They are termed

- as gyne-android or andro-gynecoid, etc

- All types of combinations are possible except anthropoid with platypelloid.

 

There may be 14 types of parent pelvis either in pure form or in combination.

questions.text: The type of uterine contraction shown in the given image is due to
questions.solution:
The type of uterine contraction shown in the given image is due to cervical dystocia.

Other types of uterine contractions are:

Asymmetrical contraction

Spastic lower segment

Normal uterine

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image
questions.solution:
• The condition given in the image is Herpes Genitalis.
  • It is a recurrent STD infection caused by the doublestranded DNA of herpes simplex virus (almost 80% are type-II infections).
  • The incubation period is 3–7 days.
  • Herpes simplex virus type I affects only 30% vulval lesions.
  • It mostly affects women between 20 and 30 years.

 

Known complications include encephalitis, urinary tract involvement causing retention of urine, severe pain or both.

questions.text: False statement regarding risk factors for scar rupture is

choices.text: More the number (>2) of prior cesarean delivery
Augmentation of labor [with high dose oxytocin (>20mU/min)]
Women having single layer uterine closure in prior cesarean delivery compared to double layer closure

questions.solution:
Risk Factors for Scar Rupture

  • More the number (>2) of prior cesarean delivery
  • Interpregnancy interval <24 months
  • Induced labor
  • Augmentation of labor [with high dose oxytocin (>20mU/min)]
  • Women having single layer uterine closure in prior cesarean delivery compared to double layer closure

questions.text: Identify the image given below
questions.solution:
The given image describes the Retraction ring, also known as Bandl’s ring.

After each contraction of the upper segment, the muscles do not return to their previous length, but tension remains essentially the same. By comparison, in the lower segment, successive lengthening of the fibers with labor is accompanied by thinning, normally to only a few millimeters in the thinnest part.

As a result of the lower segment thinning and concomitant upper segment thickening, a boundary between the two is marked by a ridge on the inner uterine surface - the physiological retraction ring.

When the thinning of the lower uterine segment is extreme, as in obstructed labor, the ring is prominent and forms a pathological retraction ring. This abnormal condition is also known as the Bandl ring.

Always situated at the junction of upper and lower segment,the position progressively moves upwards.

A constriction ring has been said to be a localized tetany of the uterus that occurs in prolonged labor with rupture of the membranes. It is usually localized to a thickened area of the myometrium over a point of fetal body.

A Constriction ring risks obstructing the descent of the baby and/ or placenta but does not risk uterine rupture while Bandl's ring (or Pathologic Retraction ring) is caused by obstructed descent and, if uncorrected, the uterus may rupture.

This is the image of a physiological retraction ring and a pathological retraction ring(showing thickened upper segment)

questions.text: Identify the instrument given in the image
questions.solution:
Rubin’s cannula

  • It is used in hysterosalpingogram recording,while the dye is instilled into the uterine cavity, the cone prevents retrograde spill into the vagina.

Used to detect the patency of fallopian tube in case of infertility and also in diagnosis of:

  • Cervical incompetence
  • Congenital anomalies of uterus
  • Asherman’s syndrome

questions.text: Type of breech commonly present in primigravidae is
questions.solution:
Frank breech (Breech with extended legs)-most common type of breech seen in primigravidae.

Flexed breech(complete breech)-commonly present in multiparae.

Footling presentation.

questions.text: The commonest form of postpartum traumatic neuritis is
questions.solution:
The commonest form of obstetric palsy encountered in puerperium is foot drop.

Postpartum traumatic neuritis is also known as obstetric palsy. Usually unilateral and appears shortly after delivery or during the first day postpartum or so. Due to stretching of the lumbosacral trunk by the prolapsed intervertebral disk between L5 and S1.

Neurological examination reveals a lower motor neuron type of lesion with flaccidity and wasting of the muscles in areas supplied by the femoral nerve or lumbosacral plexus. Sensory loss is often present.

questions.text: Peak level of LH needed for ovulation is
questions.solution:
Peak level of 75 ng/mL of LH is needed for ovulation.

  • LH is a water-soluble glycoprotein of high molecular weight secreted by b-cells; it also contains 115 amino acids.
  • LH pulse occurs only dur­ing sleep initially, but later extends throughout the day.
  • Pro­gesterone secretion begins 34 h after LH peak.
  • The LH surge precedes ovulation by 24–36 h.

This time relationship of LH peak to ovulation is helpful in predicting the exact time of ovulation in infertile women on gonadotropin therapy, making it possible to re­trieve ova in in-vitro fertilization and to arrange for timely artificial insemination to enhance chances of conception.

questions.text: True statement regarding external cephalic version is

choices.text: Successful version reduces the risk of caesarean section
CTG should ideally be done before and after the procedure

questions.solution:
External Cephalic Version

  • Successful rate of version is 65%
  • Successful version reduces the risk of caesarean section
  • CTG should ideally be done before and after the procedure
  • Prior sonography should be a routine
  • Version in the early weeks is easy but chance of reversion is more
  • Late version may be difficult because of increasing size of the fetus and diminishing volume of liquor amnii. However, the use of uterine relaxant (tocolysis) has made the version at later weeks less difficult.

Benefits of ECV are

  • Reduction in the incidence of breech presentation at term,
  • Reduction in the incidence of breech delivery (Vaginal or cesarean) and the associated complications
  • Reduction in the incidence of cesarean delivery by 5%

Successful version is likely in cases of:

  • Complete breech
  • Non engaged breech
  • Sacro anterior position (fetal back anteriorly)
  • Adequate liquor
  • Non obese patient

questions.text: True about cervix to corpus ratio  before puberty is
questions.solution:
The relationship between the length of the cervix and that of the body of the uterus varies with age.

Timeline Cervix to corpus ratio
Before pu­berty 2:1
At puberty 1:2
during the reproductive years 1:3 or even 1:4.
After menopause whole organ atrophies and the portio vaginalis may eventually disappear

questions.text: The delivery of after coming head is by all of the following methods except
questions.solution:
Frank breech extraction (Pinard’s maneuver)

  • It is done by intrauterine manipulation (for breech decomposition) to convert a frank breech to a footling breech.
  • This is possible when the membranes have ruptured recently.

The delivery of After coming head is by 3 main mechanism

  • Burns-Marshall method
  • Forceps delivery
  • Malar flexion and shoulder traction(modified Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique)

questions.text: Name the incision given in the image
questions.solution:
Duhrssen’s incision

  • Can be made at 2 and 10 O’ clock position on the cervix
  • Done for delivery of head through an incompletely dilated cevix

Joel-Cohen incision - skin incision used for Caesarian section

Pfannenstiel incision-Abdominal incision

Cherny incision-gynecologic surgery

questions.text: False statement regarding prolonged labor is

choices.text: Prolonged labor is not synonymous with inefficient uterine contraction
A latent phase that exceeds 20 hours in primigravidae or 14 hours in multiparae is abnormal
Mean duration of latent phase is about 8 hours in a primi and 4 hours in a multi
Prolonged latent phase is an indication for cesarean delivery

questions.solution:
• Prolonged latent phase is not an indication for cesarean delivery.
  • The labor is said to be prolonged when the combined duration of the first and second stage is more than the arbitrary time limit of 18 hours. 
  • The prolongation may be due to protracted cervical dilatation in the first stage and/or inadequate descent of the presenting part during the first or second stage of labor.
  • Labor is considered prolonged when the cervical dilatation rate is less than 1 cm/h and descent of the presenting part is less than 1 cm/h for a period of minimum 4 hours observation (WHO-1994).
  • Prolonged labor is not synonymous with inefficient uterine contraction.
  • A latent phase that exceeds 20 hours in primigravidae or 14 hours in multiparae is abnormal.
  • Mean duration of latent phase is about 8 hours in a primi and 4 hours in a multi.

questions.text: Arcuate uterus comes under which class of mullerian anomalies according to WHO?
questions.solution:
Class 6 –Arcuate Uterus.The classification is only upto class 6

 

WHO classification of mullerian anomalies

  • Class 1 –Mullerian agenesis
  • Class 2- Unicornuate Uterus
  • Class 3 – Didelphys Uterus
  • Class 4- Bicornuate Uterus
  • Class 5- Septate Uterus
  • Class 6- Arcuate Uterus

questions.text: Most common traumatic cause of PPH is
questions.solution:
• Most common traumatic cause of PPH is Extensive Cervical tear.
  • Minor degree of cervical tear is invariable during first delivery and requires no treatment.
  • Isolated vaginal tears or lacerations without involvement of the perineum or cervix are not uncommon, these are usually seen following instrumental or manipulative delivery.

questions.text: Silver is one of the components in which of the following IUCD?
questions.solution:
• Nova T is nothing but CuT, where silver is added to copper wire thereby increasing lifespan of CuT from 3 years to 5 Years.
  • Mirena (32 x 32 mm) contains 52 mg LNG, eluting 20 mcg daily . It can be retained for 5 years.
  • Copper T 380A, known as Paraguard, has a lifespan of 10 years.

questions.text: False statement regarding scar dehiscence is

choices.text: Disruption of part of scar and not the entire length
Uterine cavity and peritoneal cavity become continuous
Bleeding is almost nil or minimal

questions.solution:
The uterine cavity and peritoneal cavity become continuous in case of scar rupture and not dehiscence.

Scar dehiscence is the asymptomatic separation of the uterine scar without the involvement of the peritoneal coat. It is characterized by:

  • Only a part of the scar is disrupted and not the entire length (Option A)
  • The fetal membranes are intact (Option B)
  • Almost nil or minimal bleeding (Option D)

Scar rupture is characterized by the complete separation of all the uterine layers including the serosa. It is characterized by:

  • The entire length of the scar is disrupted
  • Rupture of the membranes with varying amounts of bleeding from the margins or from its extension
  • The uterine cavity and peritoneal cavity become continuous

questions.text: Formation of tubo ovarian complex is considered as which stage of PID?
questions.solution:
Formation of tubo ovarian complex  is seen in stage 3

Stages Condition
Stage I Acute salpingitis without peritonitis—no adhesions
Stage II Acute salpingitis with peritonitis—purulent discharge  
Stage III Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex
Stage IV Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess
Stage V Tubercular salpingitis

questions.text: Positive Homan’s sign is seen in
questions.solution: A positive Homan’s sign—pain in the calf on dorsiflexion of the foot may be present in Deep vein thrombosis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl investigated for primary amenorrhea is diagnosed with Mayer–Rokitansky–Kuster–Hauser (MRHK) syndrome. Which of the following characteristics is not associated with this condition?

choices.text: Axillary and pubic hair is present

questions.solution:
The patients diagnosed with Mayer–Rokitansky–Kuster–Hauser (MRHK) syndrome have ovaries that are anatomically and functionally normal.

Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome or Mullerian agenesis is a condition wherein there is a congenital absence of the uterus and the vagina. The patients have a Karyotype of 46 XX, so the gonads present are ovaries. 

The patient's secondary sexual characteristics are well-developed (Option A and B) with normal external genitalia. The ovaries are normal but have an absence of the uterus and the upper part of the vagina. The patients usually have a blind-ended vaginal pouch. Diagnosis is made with the help of pelvic sonography and  MRI. Patients may have rudimentary Mullerian bulbs without an endometrial cavity.

The investigation algorithm for primary amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characteristics is given below:

Related Pearl: Disorders of Sexual Development

Disorder

Complete androgen insensitivity

Mullerian agenesis

Turner syndrome

Complete XY dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome)

Cause

X-linked mutation of androgen receptor

Hypoplastic or absent Mullerian ductal system

Also called Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome

Complete or partial absence of one X chromosome

SRY gene mutation on the Y chromosome

Reproductive organs

Absent uterus and upper vagina, cryptorchid testis

Absent or rudimentary uterus and upper vagina, normal ovaries

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Breast

Yes

Yes

Variable

No

Axillary/Pubic hair

Minimal to absent

Normal

Normal

Minimal to absent

Karyotype

46 XY

46 XX

45 XO or 

45 X mosaicism

46 XY

 

Note: 

Turner's syndrome have different chromosomal anomalies:

  • 45 XO which is seen in 40-50% patients 
  • 45 X mosaicism (eg, 45,X/46,XX or 45,X/47,XXX, or 45,X mosaics with the X chromosome anomalies)

questions.text: Identify the image given below:
questions.solution:
• Karman canula is a long tubular structure  made of plastic or metal
  • Types Rigid or Flexible
  • Sizes 4 to 12 mm
  • Superior overhanging edge acts as a curette
  • The number of cannula corresponds to the diameter in millimeters.
  • A plastic cannula is preffered because it is less traumatic ,transparent and disposable

questions.text: All are used in treatment of resistant genital tuberculosis except
questions.solution:
Pyrazinamide is not useful in resistant genital tuberculosis

Drugs used in resistant tuberculosis are:

  • Capreomycin
  • Kanamycin
  • Ethionamide
  • Para-Aminosalicylic acid
  • Cycloserine
